qas.question: Towards the end of what century did it become important for more people in Dutch colonies to speak Dutch?
What VIP segment of the population in Dutch colonies learned Dutch to participate in business and government?
What was the Dutch government afraid of doing if they taught their colonies Dutch?
Leaders wanted to hang onto knowledge of the Dutch language because it's the language of what?

context: Unlike other European nations, the Dutch chose not to follow a policy of language expansion amongst the indigenous peoples of their colonies. In the last quarter of the <a0_0>19th<a0_0/> century, however, a <a1_0>local elite<a1_0/> gained proficiency in Dutch so as to meet the needs of expanding bureaucracy and business. Nevertheless, the Dutch government remained reluctant to teach Dutch on a large scale for fear of <a2_0>destabilising the colony<a2_0/>. Dutch, the language of <a3_0>power<a3_0/>, was supposed to remain in the hands of the leading elite.
